title: RS22581
content: The Securities Act of 1933 requires securities to be registered with the SEC before being offered to the public. The registration statement includes a prospectus for purchasers and Part II for inspection. Schedule A outlines the required information, including underwriters, business details, shareholders, and financial information. The prospectus must comply with Section 10(a) of the Act. Commission regulations also provide additional requirements. The Securities Act of 1933 requires registration of securities with the SEC, including specific information in the prospectus as outlined in Section 10(a). The Act also exempts certain transactions and securities, such as private placements and government securities. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 mandates ongoing disclosure through periodic reports for issuers with securities traded on a national exchange or meeting specific asset and shareholder criteria. Registration with the SEC is required under the 1934 Act for such issuers. Securities held by a certain number of shareholders must register under the 1934 Act with the SEC and file periodic reports. Sections 12, 13, and 14 outline detailed reporting requirements, with exemptions provided. Failure to disclose material information is actionable under Section 18(a) and Section 10(b) grants a private right of action for investors. The Investment Company Act of 1940 protects investors by requiring investment companies to register with the SEC and disclose specified information. Compliance is necessary for participation in certain securities activities, with restrictions on affiliations and interests of directors, officers, and employees. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 defines an investment adviser as someone who advises on securities value or investment advisability for compensation. Investment advisers must register with the SEC to conduct business and are subject to increased sanctions under the Insider Trading Sanctions Act of 1984 to deter insider trading. The Insider Trading and Securities Fraud Enforcement Act of 1988 increased sanctions against insider trading by allowing the commission to seek civil penalties up to three times the profit gained or loss avoided for trading with material nonpublic information. This act also expanded penalties for those who fail to prevent insider trading and increased jail terms and fines for securities law violations. The Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 addressed frivolous shareholder lawsuits by limiting them in federal courts and appointing a lead plaintiff. It aimed to prevent misuse of inside information by requiring broker-dealers and investment advisers to establish written policies. The act also initiated a bounty program for informants assisting the SEC and increased sanctions for securities law violations. The Securities Litigation Uniform Standards Act of 1998 (SLUSA) was enacted to address perceived failures of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 (PSLRA) in curbing securities fraud litigation abuses. SLUSA limits shareholder lawsuits in federal courts, appoints lead plaintiffs, ensures full disclosure of settlement terms, provides safe harbor for forward-looking statements, and mandates auditor disclosure of corporate fraud. It aims to prevent plaintiffs from circumventing PSLRA requirements by allowing securities fraud cases only in federal courts under a uniform standard. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 was enacted in response to corporate scandals like Enron and WorldCom. It established a Public Company Accounting Oversight Board, restricted accounting firms from providing certain services to companies they audit, and required additional disclosures for public companies and their officers. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 established a Public Company Accounting Oversight Board and restricted accounting firms from providing certain services to companies they audit. Dodd-Frank, enacted in response to the financial downturn, made significant changes to financial regulation, affecting the securities industry in various ways, including the regulation of over-the-counter swaps markets. Dodd-Frank, enacted in response to the financial downturn, made significant changes to financial regulation, affecting the securities industry in various ways. Title IX of Dodd-Frank sets out new powers of the SEC, including creating an Office of the Investor Advocate and a whistleblower bounty program for securities fraud disclosure. It also expands regulation of credit rating agencies, requires shareholder votes on executive compensation, and establishes a Public Company Accounting Oversight Board. Additionally, Title XV requires disclosure by publicly traded companies of minerals from the Democratic Republic of the Congo benefiting armed groups. The SEC issues rules for disclosure of minerals from the Democratic Republic of the Congo benefiting armed groups. The STOCK Act prohibits insider trading by Members of Congress and employees. The JOBS Act aims to ease securities reporting requirements for small businesses and startups, with Title I for emerging growth companies and Title III for crowdfunding being notable. An emerging growth company, with annual revenues less than $1 billion, can phase in SEC regulations and submit draft registration statements confidentially. Title III exempts certain companies from the 1933 Securities Act's registration requirements if specific conditions are met, including limits on securities sold and requirements for investors.
